body.p:
I am in receipt of
your letters of Nov. & Decr. and the
Occident for those months. By
this Steamer Mr. Alfred Delgado
of this city leaves for New York. I have
handed him ? sovereigns in gold to be
delivered to you, on your applying
to Messrs Henry & De Cordova, at whose
office the money will be left. This is
all I had in hand. Perhaps a few more
copies (say 3 or 4) of the pirated edition,
of the Pentateuch with the Sabbath Prayer
may obtain a sale, there having lately
been an inquiry for them. The question
respecting the amot. of produce raised in the time of slavery and of emancipation
can only be answered by reference to

statistical tables, which are not easily
procurable. On general data the following
may be relied on—130,000 ? Sugar were
often annually exported during slavery;
whereas the highest quantity shipped
annually since emancipation has not
exceeded 37000 ?; and that figure
was only attained in 1862, the crop having
raised between that and 22000 ?, the
lowest yield in 1855. In coffee the falling
off has been equally great, no crop since
Emancipation having been higher than 6
millions of pounds, and in some years not more
than 4 millions. Before 1846, emancipation
having taken place in 1834, matters began
to turn in favor of the planter, when the
abolition of the differential duties by the
British Parliament depressed sugar Culitva-
tion wherever Emancipation had been established
to an alarming extent, whilst it proportionately
raised it wherever slavery existed. This
suicidal and unjust measure, a ? to
the Free Trader, gave Louisiana and Cuba
such a ?, that cane cultivation,

which was about being abandoned in the
former, and entailed ruinous lapses on planters
in the latter, owing to the viability of slave
produce labor to compete with free labor when protected
by the differential duties,—began to attain that
prosperity in slave countries which they it
has since maintained. The immense
number of small settlers, formerly slaves,
in this Island, increased by the abundance
and cheapness of land, has caused a dearth
of labor in the market, which only immigration
can supply. But colored laborers, however
large the number imported will not resus-
citate Jamaica. She wants a large influx
of white settlers in the beautiful and
salubrious mountain regions, where whites
can labor without the fear of yellow fever
or other tropical diseases. I will write
you more on this topic on some future occasion.

You and I are of the same age
it appears. I made 56 in Novr. God
grant that the balance of your days
may be more happy than the first part
has been and that you may receive
Even in this life the reward so justly

your due for your arduous labors
in the good cause. The Revd Mr. Myers
will address you, he has already found
he is not reposing on a bed of roses.
He will possibly state particulars.

Your accounts of Miss Gratz are
full of melancholy interest. I have many
times sat down to write her, but have
abandoned the idea, lest any querulous
word might slip into the sheet and
give her pain, which I wish to avoid.

When will this horrible war come
to an end? What is slavery, with all its
horrors to this inhuman and cruel
butchery which rivals in atrocity and
barbarity the sanguinary deeds of Jamelane?
or Genghis Khan? O may God soon send
peace, for it is sickening to humanity to
watch even at a distance the course struggle.
